subNodes.conversationText: A woman sat beneath the shade of an oak tree. She was wearing -- and sweating through -- at least an ounce of makeup. The blanket she sat on was strewn with parchment, and she'd turned a tree stump at her side into a table for a quill and ink.

"You know," she said to <FirstName>, "I thought these woods were just woods -- nothing special about them. I said so to the minister, and I said so to the ambassador. I would have said the same to the king, but he's so old that he can't hear anything."

"Well, our first day taught me a lesson. The Congress of Moths jumped right out of a legend and into our camp. And now, during our second week, a witch stumbles through. Welcome. I'm Oxana, aide-de-camp to the Minister of Peace."
"I understand you're supposed to talk to the minister. He's at the king's tent with the ambassador."
"Do you have any news from the outside world?"
"Back in the capital, everyone is nervous about what will happen when King Setus dies. I don't pay much attention to news from other parts. It's never reliable."
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"What does the aide-de-camp of the minister do, exactly?"

"Oh, you don't want to hear about that. My duties are very dull. Accounts, logistics, that sort of thing. My life before serving the minister was much more exciting, but I'm now old enough to recognize the charm of a little dullness."
"Your life before? What was that like?"
"What could possibly make you interested in all that?" Oxana said. Despite the woman's words, the young witch could tell that she was gratified by <his/her> curiosity.
"Go on. I have a few minutes to spare."
"Truly? Well, I'll have to begin quite far back."

"When I was young, there were many who loved me. I don't pretend to have beauty now -- or, if I do, it's the beauty of a painting, not the beauty of a young person. Look at my face. I'm a good painter, aren't I?"
"I thought that was your natural complexion," lied <FirstName>.

"Anyway -- there were many who loved me, and none I loved back. My father was a distant cousin of the king, and my mother was the daughter of a courtier. I was brought up in the court of Setus II. I was spoiled and insincere. No one satisfied me. Everyone fell short. I had no interest in anything and felt life to be only the ebb and flow of dull, familiar pleasures."
"I suppose not!" laughed Oxana. "What happened next was more extraordinary."

"When I was eighteen, I accepted the hand of a rich but nameless merchant. Everyone turned against me. But how could I say no? He had more money than the petty lords who’d thrown themselves in my way... But it wasn’t just that. He was handsome, a man of the world outside Dudow. And I relished the rumors of danger and disgrace that clung to him."

"When I was eighteen, I accepted the hand of a rich but nameless merchant. Everyone turned against me. But how could I say no? He had more money than the petty lords who’d thrown themselves in my way... But it wasn’t just that. He was handsome, a man of the world outside Dudow. And I relished the rumors of danger and disgrace that clung to him."

"Well, I soon learned that he was no merchant at all, but a pirate. We had a wild life together. He took me up and down strange coasts, across the sea and back, our adventures bound only by the horizons… In my own stupid and not very deep way I think I loved him."

"That life didn't last long. One day, we plundered a merchant ship. The ship appeared to be alone but was in the rear of a Dudovian naval convoy. Officers captured and executed him before my eyes. I can still see the sun gleaming on the ocean... I begged them to spare me, pleading my connections, spluttering the names of half-forgotten friends from my past life."
"It's as good as a story, isn't it?"

"That life didn't last long. One day, we plundered a merchant ship. The ship appeared to be alone but was in the rear of a Dudovian naval convoy. Officers captured and executed him before my eyes. I can still see the sun gleaming on the ocean... I begged them to spare me, pleading my connections, spluttering the names of half-forgotten friends from my past life."
"The right connections have power even in the middle of the ocean."
"They spared me and took me home. My parents were dead, and I found myself estranged from everyone I'd known."
"Someone in the royal court must have taken pity on you."

"I had resources of my own. Piracy taught me more than my tutors. I knew how to make a fortune out of others' misfortunes, how to lend copper and collect gold, and how to balance the love of having money with the love of enjoying it. I'd secretly kept some of my husband's treasure, and with that handful of jewels set myself up as a person of business."
"It wasn't that hard. I was never sentimental -- except where my husband was concerned."

"I had resources of my own. Piracy taught me more than my tutors. I knew how to make a fortune out of others' misfortunes, how to lend copper and collect gold, and how to balance the love of having money with the love of enjoying it. I'd secretly kept some of my husband's treasure, and with that handful of jewels set myself up as a person of business."

"That was my life for ten years. At the end of them, I decided to try court life again. My pedigree still had value among those people, and my new riches didn't hurt. Eventually I became what you behold today, the aide-de-camp of the Minister of Peace."
"Thank you for indulging me. I imagine that a witch's indulgence is a very rare thing. But now I should return to my ledgers and invoices -- unless you had something else to ask?"
"No, that's all for now. Farewell, Oxana."
"If you have enough power, a little scandal is no disadvantage. Like wine, it can go bad -- But give it enough time and the proper care, and scandal ages into something everyone loves."
"Thank you for indulging me. I imagine that a witch's indulgence is a very rare thing. But now I should return to my ledgers and invoices -- unless you had something else to ask?"
"They spared me and took me home. My parents were dead, and I found myself estranged from everyone I'd known."
"I'm bad at describing looks. He was thin but strong, a traveler, and he had a rough sort of beard, and -- well, you get the idea. He was himself, which was all the handsomeness in the world to me."

"Well, I soon learned that he was no merchant at all, but a pirate. We had a wild life together. He took me up and down strange coasts, across the sea and back, our adventures bound only by the horizons… In my own stupid and not very deep way I think I loved him."
"Yes. Very good," said the witch, not sure what <he/she> was supposed to say.

"Anyway -- there were many who loved me, and none I loved back. My father was a distant cousin of the king, and my mother was the daughter of a courtier. I was brought up in the court of Setus II. I was spoiled and insincere. No one satisfied me. Everyone fell short. I had no interest in anything and felt life to be only the ebb and flow of dull, familiar pleasures."
"Of course, of course. You have better things to do than listen to my tale."
"On second thought, I should be going. Farewell."
"Then let me ask you about something else."
"Do you have any news from the outside world?"
"What's your opinion of this mission to Wan?"
"On second thought, I should be going. Farewell."
"What does the aide-de-camp of the minister do, exactly?"
"What's your opinion of this mission to Wan?"
"My opinion doesn't matter, and I'm afraid the minister wouldn't approve of it if he heard it. Luckily, he hasn't asked me."
"But I have. You don't need to worry about me telling him anything."
"Witches aren't known for their trustworthiness and discretion."
"We are known for getting our way, though."
"I hope you aren't thinking of hexing me."

"If you must know, the ambassador and the minister don't see eye to eye on things. Astimund wants to strengthen friendly ties between Wan and Dudow. He wants to arrange formal, regular talks about the disputed territory. The minister wants to signal to the Grand Governor that Setus's heir is unafraid to stand up to her."
"That's an interesting analysis of the situation -- but what is your opinion?"

She lowered her voice to a whisper, and for the first time looked nervous. "I side with the ambassador. Not because I think regular talks would bring back Ghund, but because having them in place might keep the peace. "To my mind, Dudow is a child poking a bear. If the bear doesn't stir -- well then, the child can go home happy that they have poked a bear. If the bear stirs -- no more child. I don't think the child's happiness is really worth the risk."
"But would the bear take the child seriously? Could Wan really be provoked by Dudow?"

"The Grand Governor has problems of her own. Civil unrest, provincial governors who act like princes, cartels that have grown too powerful... A rich, foreign antagonist that poses little threat might be just the thing."
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"What does the aide-de-camp of the minister do, exactly?"
"What's your opinion of this mission to Wan?"
"Do you have any news from the outside world?"
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"You want me to drop the subject."
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"What harm could it do? I'll be discreet."
"Witches aren't known for their trustworthiness and discretion."
"I should get back to work. Thank you for the conversation. Next time, perhaps I can learn a little more about you. I've always wondered what a witch's life is like."
"I understand you're supposed to talk to the minister. He's at the king's tent with the ambassador."
Oxana and the young witch said hello.
